items.content_html:
In fact, reading books is considered a cognitive â€˜reserve buildingâ€™ activity that could help to protect you from Alzheimerâ€™s and related illnesses.
~ How to read more books by Christian Jarrett

First time I’ve heard that. So, reading books can help stave off Alzheimerâ€™s.
items.content_text:
> In fact, reading books is considered a cognitive â€˜reserve buildingâ€™ activity that could help to protect you from Alzheimerâ€™s and related illnesses.  
~ [How to read more books](https://psyche.co/guides/how-to-make-a-daily-habit-of-reading-more-books?utm_source=Aeon+Newsletter&utm_campaign=72d13368cc-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2020_07_30_07_31&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_411a82e59d-72d13368cc-70852215) by Christian Jarrett

First time I've heard that. So, reading books can help stave off Alzheimerâ€™s.

items.content_html:
And although TV and video games of course offer escapism, thereâ€™s nothing quite like devouring the pages of a beautiful novel, sitting quietly in one place while letting words transport you to another. Screens show you whatâ€™s happening; novels, by contrast, construct those fictions within your mind, allowing you to become anyone, and go anywhere.
~ How to read more books by Christian Jarrett

Hmmm I’d put books and videogames on the same level. It’s also very much dependent on how good a book and videogame is. While a good book can allow your mind to wander into a wonderful world full of possibilities, at the end of the day, you’re still following the story. A really good videogame on the other hand, gives you a world to play in and let’s you write your own story.
items.content_text:
> And although TV and video games of course offer escapism, thereâ€™s nothing quite like devouring the pages of a beautiful novel, sitting quietly in one place while letting words transport you to another. Screens show you whatâ€™s happening; novels, by contrast, construct those fictions within your mind, allowing you to become anyone, and go anywhere.  
~ [How to read more books](https://psyche.co/guides/how-to-make-a-daily-habit-of-reading-more-books?utm_source=Aeon+Newsletter&utm_campaign=72d13368cc-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2020_07_30_07_31&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_411a82e59d-72d13368cc-70852215) by Christian Jarrett

Hmmm I'd put books and videogames on the same level. It's also very much dependent on how good a book and videogame is. While a good book can allow your mind to wander into a wonderful world full of possibilities, at the end of the day, you're still following the story. A really good videogame on the other hand, gives you a world to play in and let's you write your own story.

items.content_html:
If youâ€™re one of these people, opening a book might have become something to do when you havenâ€™t got anything else going on, which is almost never. Itâ€™s as if you decided at some point, likely without conscious thought, that even though you love books, book reading is effectively the least important thing in your life â€“ youâ€™ll squeeze it in, if you can.
~ How to read more books by Christian Jarrett

I have a feeling that a lot of it has to do with the smartphones in our pockets.

items.content_html: Any time you are writing IO code, like something that saves or moves files to different locations, you should wrap the code in a try-catch. Without a try-catch, if one of the “move file” attempts fail, the whole process breaks down and you end up losing your files.
items.content_text: Any time you are writing IO code, like something that saves or moves files to different locations, you should wrap the code in a try-catch. Without a try-catch, if one of the "move file" attempts fail, the whole process breaks down and you end up losing your files.

items.content_html:
Many church goers have been unable to participate in the liturgy for months. Some are just now beginning to return. Where is the grace in this hiatus and slow trickle back? Perhaps it gives us a chance to pause and ask ourselves where chasms have formed between how we regard and treat others with the radical faith Jesus gifted us.

Perhaps, it gives us a moment to simply ask: Whatâ€™s the point of going, if the bread changes, but we donâ€™t?
~ Sometimes I Wonder, What If the Bread Changes but We Donâ€™t? by Christopher Alt, SJ
items.content_text:
> Many church goers have been unable to participate in the liturgy for months. Some are just now beginning to return. Where is the grace in this hiatus and slow trickle back? Perhaps it gives us a chance to pause and ask ourselves where chasms have formed between how we regard and treat others with the radical faith Jesus gifted us.

> Perhaps, it gives us a moment to simply ask: Whatâ€™s the point of going, if the bread changes, but we donâ€™t?  
~ [Sometimes I Wonder, What If the Bread Changes but We Donâ€™t?](https://thejesuitpost.org/2020/08/sometimes-i-wonder-what-if-the-bread-changes-but-we-dont/) by Christopher Alt, SJ

items.content_html:
When it comes to achieving a good life, we often think about the things we need to start doing. The habits we need to add. The practices we need to optimize.

Yet research, and reams of anecdotal experience, show that avoiding negative things has a far bigger influence on outcomes than adopting positive ones.
~ Sunday Firesides: Want a Good Life? Just Donâ€™t Do Stupid Stuff by Brett and Kate McKay
items.content_text:
> When it comes to achieving a good life, we often think about the things we need to start doing. The habits we need to add. The practices we need to optimize.  

> Yet research, and reams of anecdotal experience, show that avoiding negative things has a far bigger influence on outcomes than adopting positive ones.  
~ [Sunday Firesides: Want a Good Life? Just Donâ€™t Do Stupid Stuff](https://www.artofmanliness.com/articles/sunday-firesides-want-a-good-life-just-dont-do-stupid-stuff/) by Brett and Kate McKay

items.content_html: Davin is such a good boy. I setup the Xbox to display a “Remember to take a break” message whenever someone has been playing for over an hour. When the message showed up today, I looked at him said, “Hey, take a break.” He replied with “Ok” and quickly turned off the Xbox.
items.content_text: Davin is such a good boy. I setup the Xbox to display a *"Remember to take a break"* message whenever someone has been playing for over an hour. When the message showed up today, I looked at him said, *"Hey, take a break."* He replied with *"Ok"* and quickly turned off the Xbox.

items.content_html: Years ago, my definition of afford was, if I can keep paying the monthly payment, I can afford it. Nowadays that definition has changed to, if I can’t buy it with cash, then I can’t afford it.
items.content_text: Years ago, my definition of *afford* was, if I can keep paying the monthly payment, I can *afford* it. Nowadays that definition has changed to, if I can't buy it with cash, then I can't *afford* it.

items.content_html:
Smoothing the way through â€˜lawnmower parentingâ€™ serves to make your children ready for smooth roads only. Constant hovering around your children only makes them even more reliant on your presence. As the person who loves them most, donâ€™t ask yourself what you can do to help your children every day, but what you can do to help them help themselves. Thatâ€™s a parenting action that will truly prepare them for the bumps, twists and turns of the life journeys stretching ahead of them.
~ How to raise a resilient child by Judith Locke
items.content_text:
> Smoothing the way through â€˜lawnmower parentingâ€™ serves to make your children ready for smooth roads only. Constant hovering around your children only makes them even more reliant on your presence. As the person who loves them most, donâ€™t ask yourself what you can do to help your children every day, but what you can do to help them help themselves. Thatâ€™s a parenting action that will truly prepare them for the bumps, twists and turns of the life journeys stretching ahead of them.  
~ [How to raise a resilient child](https://psyche.co/guides/to-help-your-children-put-the-helicopter-in-the-hangar?utm_source=Aeon+Newsletter&utm_campaign=b16ae6427a-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2020_07_16_05_40&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_411a82e59d-b16ae6427a-70852215) by Judith Locke

items.content_html:
When you prioritise your childrenâ€™s rights over their responsibilities, you prevent them from learning the skill of accountability and from experiencing the wellbeing benefits of contributing to society. Remind your children that there is equal, if not more, happiness in what they do for others than in what others do for them.
~ How to raise a resilient child by Judith Locke

items.content_html:
But in a world where so many aspects of our lives are mediated by our smartphones the techos also provide a more concrete record of our lives, says Yuri Kimura, who like most of Hobonichiâ€™s staff is an avid user. â€œAs long as our life is offline, we need this,â€ she says. Thatâ€™s a trend thatâ€™s shared with people all over the world as seen in the rise of the hugely popular pen-and-paper organisation system of bullet journals.
~ Why Japan is obsessed with paper by Edd Gent

That’s true. A digital record of our lives… is… digital. It’s not something I can reach out and hold physically. Writing something down on a planner, diary or journal, is a more concrete record of our lives.

Thatâ€™s a trend thatâ€™s shared with people all over the world as seen in the rise of the hugely popular pen-and-paper organisation system of bullet journals.  
~ [Why Japan is obsessed with paper](https://www.bbc.com/future/article/20200204-japans-intriguing-love-of-paper) by Edd Gent

That's true. A digital record of our lives... is... digital. It's not something I can reach out and hold physically. Writing something down on a planner, diary or journal, is a more concrete record of our lives.

items.content_html:
I was running a test and kept running into the error below. I would not allow myself to check-in my code unless my tests passed. Battled with this fates-cursed error for over an hour. I double-checked my test project app.config file and the relevant client.config files - everything looked right.

It turns out, there was a typo in the Web.config file for another service. See, the service method that I’m trying to test, was running inside another service. So, in addition to the test project’s app.config file, I also needed to double-check the other service’s Web.config file. And that other Web.config file had a fates-cursed typo on it…

The binding at system.serviceModel/bindings/basicHttpBinding does not have a configured binding named ‘BasicHttpBinding_IXXXXXX’. This is an invalid value for bindingConfiguration.
items.content_text:
I was running a test and kept running into the error below. I would not allow myself to check-in my code unless my tests passed. Battled with this fates-cursed error for over an hour. I double-checked my test project app.config file and the relevant client.config files - everything looked right. 

It turns out, there was a typo in the Web.config file for another service. See, the service method that I'm trying to test, was running inside another service. So, in addition to the test project's app.config file, I also needed to double-check the other service's Web.config file. And that other Web.config file had a fates-cursed typo on it... 

> The binding at system.serviceModel/bindings/basicHttpBinding does not have a configured binding named 'BasicHttpBinding_IXXXXXX'. This is an invalid value for bindingConfiguration.

People were created to be loved. Things were created to be used. The reason why the world is in chaos is because things are being loved and people are being used.

~ Love People, Not Things by Joshua Becker

Good read.

items.content_html:
So, I noticed that unordered lists don’t show up correctly when using the Marfa theme. The list markers are missing. Adding the script below to my custom css seems to have fixed it.


#post-list li article ul li {
    list-style-type: disc;
}

Some things to try out in the next few days:

  • Switch out the Disqus comments system on my dev blog for utterances. Since it is a dev blog, I figure most of the people who visit would most likely have Github accounts.
  • Try to install Hyvor Talk on this micro.blog hosted blog. The first day I joined, I saw a post from someone saying they successfully installed it on their blog. After playing around with the custom theme option, I think it is doable. Will give it a try.
items.content_text:
Some things to try out in the next few days:

- Switch out the Disqus comments system on my dev blog for [utterances](https://utteranc.es/). Since it is a dev blog, I figure most of the people who visit would most likely have Github accounts.
- Try to install [Hyvor Talk](https://talk.hyvor.com/) on this micro.blog hosted blog. The first day I joined, I saw a post from someone saying they successfully installed it on their blog. After playing around with the custom theme option, I think it is doable. Will give it a try.

items.content_html:
Found another use for this micro.blog/micro journal of mine. I can use it to quickly store ideas for posts to write on my dev blog. Later on, I can come back here, find the post I wrote, flesh it out and post it on my dev blog. A possible benefit to would-be readers is that, even in its most basic form, it might already have enough info to help other people.

Normally, I would write these things down on my bullet journal. But I have noticed that I never seem to turn those notes into blog posts. Part of the problem is that it takes awhile for me to write down a solution to a technical problem. So, when writing things down, I sort of skimp on the details. When I come back to my notes, days, weeks, months later, I don’t have enough info to turn it into a blog post. I’m hoping this practice would help me get more content up on my dev blog.
items.content_text:
Found another use for this micro.blog/micro journal of mine. I can use it to quickly store ideas for posts to write on my dev blog. Later on, I can come back here, find the post I wrote, flesh it out and post it on my dev blog. A possible benefit to would-be readers is that, even in its most basic form, it might already have enough info to help other people.

Normally, I would write these things down on my bullet journal. But I have noticed that I never seem to turn those notes into blog posts. Part of the problem is that it takes awhile for me to write down a solution to a technical problem. So, when writing things down, I sort of skimp on the details. When I come back to my notes, days, weeks, months later, I don't have enough info to turn it into a blog post. I'm hoping this practice would help me get more content up on my dev blog.

items.content_html: Was going to try and welcome new bloggers whenever I see them pop-up on the other blogging platform I am on - something that I see happen often here on micro.blog. I went from trying to figure out how to respond to someone’s untitled post, to trying to figure out what to title my own post, to feeling like I am trying to advertise myself by doing so, to just closing the window. Without a dedicated Reply button, it’s just not the same.

Without a dedicated Reply button, it's just not the same.

items.content_html:
After not being able to find one of Davin’s books in the bookshelf, I said, “Oh no, I can’t find the book.” Davin replied, “Relax Daddy, relax. We’ll find it.” Then he got off his bed, started putting on his slippers so he could help me find it.

When did he grow up so much?
items.content_text:
After not being able to find one of Davin's books in the bookshelf, I said, *"Oh no, I can't find the book."* Davin replied, *"Relax Daddy, relax. We'll find it."* Then he got off his bed, started putting on his slippers so he could help me find it. 

When did he grow up so much?

items.content_html: Was running into a build error in Visual Studio 2017. The Output window says 1 project failed, but the Error List window was empty. The only way I managed to figure out what project was failing, was to copy the contents of the window, paste it into Notepad++ and search for “FAILED”. Anyway, I finally figured out that it was the SQL database project that was failing.
items.content_text: Was running into a build error in Visual Studio 2017. The Output window says 1 project failed, but the Error List window was empty. The only way I managed to figure out what project was failing, was to copy the contents of the window, paste it into Notepad++ and search for "FAILED". Anyway, I finally figured out that it was the SQL database project that was failing.

items.content_html:
ğŸ€ Okay first, the good news. The good news is that the Dallas Mavericks have clinched a playoff spot. Thanks to the Spurs for defeating the Grizzlies tonight. The Mavs have not been in the playoffs since 2016.

Now the bad news. The bad news is that the Mavs are on a 2-game losing streak since the restart of the NBA season. They could have won both games, but gave up the lead and lost at the end. They cannot close games. And their defense is so inconsistent. At this rate, if they donâ€™t improve on those aspects of their game, I dont see them getting past the first round of the playoffs.
items.content_text:
ğŸ€ Okay first, the good news. The good news is that the Dallas Mavericks have clinched a playoff spot. *Thanks to the Spurs for defeating the Grizzlies tonight.* The Mavs have not been in the playoffs since 2016. 

Now the bad news. The bad news is that the Mavs are on a 2-game losing streak since the restart of the NBA season. They could have won both games, but gave up the lead and lost at the end. They cannot close games. And their defense is so inconsistent. At this rate, if they donâ€™t improve on those aspects of their game, I dont see them getting past the first round of the playoffs.

items.content_html:
Restart of the NBA season ğŸ€ could not have gone any better. The first two games back from the break went down to the wire. Both games ended with teams within 2 points of each other.

Brandon Ingram’s last second 3 point shot was in… before it rolled out. To be fair to the Jazz, they fought back to win the game. And Lebron, well Lebron is still Lebron. The long break from the game and his age did nothing to slow him down. Picked up his own miss to put the Lakers ahead at the end of the game.

Now I’m looking forward to the Mavericks vs Rockets game later tonight. Let’s go Mavs!
items.content_text: Restart of the NBA season ğŸ€ could not have gone any better. The first two games back from the break went down to the wire. Both games ended with teams within 2 points of each other. Brandon Ingram's last second 3 point shot was in... before it rolled out. To be fair to the Jazz, they fought back to win the game. And Lebron, well Lebron is still Lebron. The long break from the game and his age did nothing to slow him down. Picked up his own miss to put the Lakers ahead at the end of the game. Now I'm looking forward to the Mavericks vs Rockets game later tonight. Let's go Mavs!

items.content_html:
One more day before the restart of the NBA season ğŸ€. Lakers vs Clippers tomorrow – should be an interesting game. Then Rockets vs Mavericks on Friday – a good chance to see if the Mavericks have improved during the break.

With the recent news of the coronavirus outbreak in baseball âš¾ï¸, I can’t help but think that maybe, just maybe, the NBA got it right. Keeping everyone inside the NBA bubble in Florida to me is a great idea. The risk of getting infected is very low as long as no one sick is allowed in. Everyone inside can stay safe and focus on their game.
items.content_text:

With the recent news of the coronavirus outbreak in baseball âš¾ï¸, I can't help but think that maybe, just maybe, the NBA got it right. Keeping everyone inside the NBA bubble in Florida to me is a great idea. The risk of getting infected is very low as long as no one sick is allowed in. Everyone inside can stay safe and focus on their game.
